head.title: Death Row: No Room for Error

hedline.hl1: Death Row: No Room for Error

abstract.p: David E Peterson letter says high reversal rate for death penalty cases does not show that innocent people are executed, but does show that death penalty cases receive more scrutiny from the courts (July 10 James Q Wilson Op-Ed)

block.p: James Q. Wilson hits it on the nose with his July 10 Op-Ed article, ''What Death-Penalty Errors?'' The Columbia University study merely proved what we already know: courts reverse death sentences for the smallest irregularity.

James Q. Wilson hits it on the nose with his July 10 Op-Ed article, ''What Death-Penalty Errors?'' The Columbia University study merely proved what we already know: courts reverse death sentences for the smallest irregularity.

The high reversal rate for death penalty cases does not show that innocent people are executed; it shows that death penalty cases receive more scrutiny from the courts, lessening the likelihood that an innocent person will be executed.
DAVID E. PETERSON Winter Park, Fla., July 10, 2000
